div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: The interior of Littleton Coke's chambers, meagerly furnished. Coke is discovered at breakfast, reading the paper. Bob , cleaning a Meerschaum, R.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Express from China — um — um — police — um — fashionable arrivals, ha! — at Mivart's, Lord Charles Roebuck, from Paris — my schoolfellow and college chum! — perhaps he has written to me — Bob.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Any papers for me this morning?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Yes sir, one, for the income tax.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Do we pay that, Bob?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: No, sir, I wish we did.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: How comes it, that during five years' hard labour at the bar. I never have had any thing to do.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Yes sir, law is quite as unprofitable to us now, as it would be to our clients, if we had any.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Have I not angled daily in Westminster Hall?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: While I carried after you a red bag, fat with your unpaid bills, like a landing net.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I could almost repent that nature had not left me in the insignificance of my birth — what right had the son of a hard-working Yorkshire coal-owner to flaunt it at Eton and Oxford, and all because my mother, before my birth, dreamed of a woolsack, and so would call me Littleton — and yet, while my suppers and stable were declared unique — when tufted lordlings exchanged christian names with me — I thought — ha! — I see my error — mistook my money for myself — why was I given so keen a sense for enjoyment, and so limited a power of gratifying it?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: But your father at his death, sir, left you 700 l. a year.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: To support 7000 appetites, he bequeathed me at my birth, so unfortunately through life, my wants have ever exceeded my means.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Ah, sir, but wants are the servants of genius.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Say its masters rather.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Your brother in Yorkshire is rich.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Thanks to my extravagance that made him so; I have mortgaged every acre of my land to him.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: If you were to write to him, sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
I have done so;
(postman's knock)
there's the answer.
[Exit Bob .
It was my last resource.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: It feels promising, sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: "Dear brother Littleton — Your favour of the 21st ultimo has duly come to hand — am most happy to find you have not forgot Sykes Hall, and those in it. Tabby sends her love, and the Rev. Mr. Rural, his blessing — the collieries win fairly — corn is at 50 s. and mutton is looking up, and I am, your affectionate brother,
"Thomas Coke."

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Lord, sir!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
"Postcript, as to your debts, I can neither afford to give champagne suppers to your friends nor pay for the spavined horses they have to sell you; had you moderated your vanity in the entertainment of a pack of spunging spendthrifts, you had not now to stoop your pride to a set of honest tradesmen.
(tears up the letter)
I deserved it; let him keep his gold."

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: They say he is generous enough on occasion.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Oh! yes,
(bitterly)
builds charity schools and endows lying-in hospitals, while his own flesh and blood may rot in a jail; curse his generosity! his is all newspaper charity and mouth virtue, yes, I will apply to my friend; Bob, did you take that note to Lord St. James?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I found him at Mr. Deuceace's.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: It was but for 20 l. Well, where is his answer?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: He sent down his compliments, that he was gone to Florence.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The paltry — here's a fellow, now, who used to swallow my dinners and jokes in sunny times, to take away at the first post.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Yes, sir, swallows always were summer birds.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: No impertinence!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Are you at home, sir?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes.
Home! mine is a sarcasm on the word.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Lord Charles Roebuck, sir,

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Charles, my dear fellow.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The same as ever — I can almost believe myself at College again — and Bob too —

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Yes, my lord, promoted from gyp to lawyer's clerk.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: It seems but a month ago since I roasted you for courting my bed-maker — do you remember?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Remember! your lordship tied me along a form before the fire, ent out and forgot me.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
You found that night's roasting a cure for love, eh? well, I'll remember you this time, there is a plaster for your
(gives him a note)
sore memory, vanish.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Why your long residence in Paris has transmuted you from a model for young England into the type of jeune France . Some time since we parted at Alma Mater.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Three years; I started immediately for Paris, where my brother was ambassador plenipotentiary; my father wished me to graduate in diplomacy under his able surveillance .

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And your respected sire, the Home Secretary.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I have not seen the Earl since my return.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: No! to be candid with you, I'm in a scrape, so I naturally hastened to you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I have, at your service, a stock of advice, generously subscribed by my friends when I revealed to them the bottom of my purse — proceed.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The most ancient of maladies.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Oh, love?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: To distraction.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: How? vulgarly, with a woman — or fashionably, with yourself?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Listen and judge. Ten days ago, as in obedience to my father's mandate, I was on my route from Paris — my chariot was arrested by the Dover Road, by a spill, illustrated with oaths and screams.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Heroics — by Jove!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Post-boy whipping — horses kicking — old gentleman cursing — young lady screaming and fainting alternately.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lucky dog.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I disengaged the senseless fair, threw off her bonnet, and unveiled a face — oh, Coke, such a face! she gasped for breath.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You lent her some of yours?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I did — but she relapsed again.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Naturally — so you kept her alive by repeated application?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Till her father came up.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She recovered then?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Immediately — he thanked me, tucked my angel under his arm, they re-entered the righted vehicle, and drove on.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Forbid it, Venus — no — with incredible trouble I traced them. The father — the dragon who guards this Hesperian fruit, is an old East Indian Colonel, as proud as Lucifer, and as hot as his dominions — I hovered round the house for a week.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Successfully?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I saw her once for a second at the back garden gate?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: To speak to her?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I hadn't time.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: No! — Oh?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: No. So I gave her a kiss —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Excellent economy, and her name —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Is Rocket — her father, an eccentric old bully, turns his house into a barrack — mounts guard at the hall-door — the poor girl can't move without a sentry, and I believe her lady's maid is an old one-eyed corporal of artillery.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is she rich?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: She is fair.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Possibly — a thing to be admired in a danseuse or a friend's wife; but in the matrimonial stocks, done on our Western 'change, the fairest hue we recognise is yellow.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Does virtue go for nothing?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Oh! no, character is indispensible to servant maids, but virtue as a word is obsolete; we have indeed a French one like it, vertu , yes — ladies of vertu might signify articles of rarity

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Does the lexicon of fashion then abjure the sense?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Certainly not, virtue signifies the strength in a bottle of salts:

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: And vice?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: A — a fault in horses.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: And religion?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: A pew at St. George's.

sp.speaker: Roe.
Lit.
sp.p: Exactly; gold is the Medean bath of youth, possessing also a magnetic attraction for every cardinal virtue while all the plagues of Egypt are shut up in one English word, and that is poverty ; the exhibition of which, like that of the Gorgon's head, turns the hearts of your dearest friends to stone.

sp.speaker: Roe.
Lit.
sp.p:
You, perhaps, may never see the world as I do, Charles,
because I am poor — but a rich man's view of life is bounded by his parasites — he feels but through his glove and thinks all things are soft.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Then I am lost, for my angel is penniless.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Right, angels are the only things who can be poor and lovely; but to marry thus before you have given the worshipful company of mamma brokers a chance, is against all rule.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Would you have me go on parade at Hyde park, and fall in with the Rotten Row dawdles, or the light lavender apathetics — turn human insect, and spend all my life in torpor to revive only for three spring months of buzz and flutter.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Hollo!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Marry a thing whose heart has been so cured by London smoke, that she keeps her feelings in it like dried botany between the leaves of an album.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The devil.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Whose mind is bounded by her bonnet, a soul perfumed with foreign sentiment — as guiltless of old English virtues as her tongue is of their native names. No! I'll have a heart that beats with blood — a cheek that's red with it — and be no slave of such a thing of scent and paint — but strike one blow for love and human nature.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Oh, you luxurious dog! —
(embraces him)
Oh — h! if I could only afford to marry a woman instead of a banker's account; — but what obstacles oppose your epicurean intentions towards Miss Rocket?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I hear my father intends for me the double honor of a seat in the house, and a wife — my cousin, Alice, the wealthy young widow of Lord George Hawthorn.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lady Alice — who shook the very apathy of the opera last week, by demanding to be balloted into the omnibus box.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Such a wife — why do they not give her a commission in the blues, at once?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She flashed into our fashionable system like a new comet, whose eccentricity defied all known law, and quickly draw after her a train that obliterated all the constellations of St. James's, and the heavenly bodies of May-fair.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: You know her then?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: A Polka acquaintanceship! I've been introduced to her waist; — we know each other in the houses of our mutual friends — but of what use can I be here?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The greatest. My father has arranged my nomination for Closeborough, I shall be obliged to advocate his political principles in the house, to which party old Rocket is a virulent opponent.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: My father — and thus — oblige me by opposing my election, and I will answer for your success.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ha! ha! help me to your borough — why, you rascal, would you make the Home Secretary purchase in a talented member for the opposition?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Consent.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: With all my heart, I see but one obstacle — the qualification!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The three-hundred a year — that's true — stay — Coke, at Eton, you were considered a fellow of great pluck.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You flatter.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: You look tenacious of life.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I'll make you a present of the widow.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lady Alice?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: If she have not, ere this, volunteered to Morocco or Macao.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Charles, to oblige you I accept the borough — for your sake I'll encounter the widow and the five thousand a-year.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir — sir — they are come —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: They — who?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Two of the fattest clients, sir, you ever saw.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Clients — you are mad, or a fool.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Neither, sir — but I think they are both.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Stay — come here. Bob — what are they like?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: One, sir, is a very respectable old gentleman in black, white hair —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Scriven, the attorney and money lender. The other?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A responsible — sort of — sporting character.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Craft the bailiff — I'm ruined.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: What's the debt, perhaps I —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: No, Charles — to be honest with you — my hopes are too slender to bear an obligation. I'm as low in pride, now, as I am in pocket, and cannot afford to turn a friend into a creditor.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: They are just on this landing, sir.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Come with me? I can offer you a room at my father's till your election is over.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Step inside, sir; while they come in, you can go out by the other door.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Farewell, fond visions of the woolsack: Bob, give up my chattles, let them take possession.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: All right, sir, a table, two chairs, a bed, and a boot jack.

div.stage: [Exeunt at the back, followed by Bob . After a pause, knocking is heard.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Littleton! Littleton, Litt — eh! — bless me, nobody. Tom, come in.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'm here, minister; so these be brother Littleton's chambers — well, they don't look prodigal neither.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: No, no, but where is he?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And they ca' this the Temple, eh? It 'll be moire loike a coil hoile aboove ground than owt else a knaw; well, minister, you would coome up to town wi' me; here we are, what next?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My dear boy, I know that you feel an old man like me a burthen on you — now you are a great man, a member of parliament.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: That's onkind of yaw, minister, and you're not given to say cruel things; why is'nt your face the very first thing in the world I can remember, hav'nt yaw been a father to us since we were left orphans; a burthen! that's the hardest word you spoke since you taught us catechesm wi' brother Littleton sitting on one knee and I on t'oother.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Think of that, Tom, do, and to see you united again is my prayer.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But wha could'nt yaw wait until we had set down quietly in the Earl of Pompion's house, according to his invitation. 'Twas main kind of him minister, he's the Home Secretary, and the next post after I was made member o' parliament, brought me a hearty invitation to his house, that's hospitality.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: But where is Littleton?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'll tell ye: — in bed, sleeping off his last night's debauch, or wi' flushed and haggard cheek, still leaning over the gambling table.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: No, Tom, no! my little pupil, my child! a gambler! — no! he was wild, sensitive, but you know he was never —

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I know no more than this — I remember him, the rapture of my poor mother, the hope of my father — and you, you always loved him best.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Tom, Tom, don't reproach me!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Reproach, nay, not so — Nature gave him a great mind, me only an honest one. He was born for greater things than I, and so he had all that wealth could lavish on him —
I didn't grudge it him — he fed from the silver plate, I from the wooden platter — I cared nuaw't for that; but at his grand school, why did he find the houses of my lord this, and marquis that, more welcome than his own home. I don't reproach, mind — but — but when our mother died I stood alone by her — and her last breath prayed for him. I wasn't jealous, minister, but, in my father's will, the part that gave me my inheritance was writ in the hard hand of a lawyer's clerk, while the gift to Littleton, with a blessing, was penned by the trembling fingers of my father, and blotted wi' his tears. I've tried to hate him.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Tom?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I did, but I couldn't. The same strange love you all showed for him I shared wi' you — a'most against ma will — and when those short heartless letters would come, containing nowt but calls for money — money — money — I could ha' freely given ten times what I lent , for but four words of hearts' blood in 'em, if 'twor but "God bless ye, Tom."

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: And he will say so when he sees you — he will. — Think what a dear child he was — so clinging, affectionate, innocent.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ye forget, that was fifteen years ago.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Was it — bless me, so it was — but you remember how generous, and kind, and wild he was — how I doted on the trouble he used to give me; and how clever — quite over-powered my faculties. I could never teach him anything but cat's cradle.
Oh, here is his servant.

div.stage: Bob advances whistling, and sits on the table.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Where be thy measter, lad?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Beyond your clutches, vampire! oh, you may stare!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What dost mean!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why! that the paltry debt I suppose you come to sue for, will be paid.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: My debt, he knows me, then?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Unhappily he does.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is this his welcome when a come to tak him by the hand?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: By the collar, you mean — oh, there, seize — seize! — your sort don't refuse even two-pence in the pound.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: This is too much.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Stop, don't be rash! let me see the boy.
(puts on his spectacles)
My good boy, I'm sure you will tell me where your master is.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh, you precious old rascal.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Good gracious!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Arn't you ashamed of yourself?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Let me at him.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: No! no! Tom, I insist.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I say it again — you are vampires, leeches, and though I am nothing but a poor servant, before I would do a day's work like this, I'd see all the gains your trade has ever wrenched from misery sunk to the bottom of the sea — ach!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Well minister, ar't satisfied now?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: He never could intend —

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Intend — didn't he know us — he spoke of my debt — oh, 'twas done by his orders — let us go.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: He called me an old rascal — and asked me if I wasn't ashamed of myselfa — shamed of — coming.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Come, come, your errand's over — forget him.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: To me — to me — my hopes — my fond, fond hopes of seeing him again — of reconciling — of — Oh, Tom!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And I, too — but no matter — I loos him off for ever — you shall return to-day to Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: No, not yet — there's some — some mistake — forgive him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I cared nowt for what he said o' me, but to insoolt you, his old friend, his father.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Yes — but he could not mean to — to —

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, dommed if ye beant crying. The villain — coom — don't take on so — the — the —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: No — never mind.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I wouldn't, if I could only get one crack at his poll, I'd forgive him.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Don't be violent. I can't — I won't believe my ears against my heart. I'll see him — I'll talk to him as I used.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The heartless reprobate.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Tom, I'll not allow you to speak so of your little brother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, 'taint bad enough, that's sure.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: God bless me! there — your violence has made me swear — I declare I shall be angry: now my dear Tom — if you will only leave it all to me, and have patience, you will see that I am right.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Go on — expose him again —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: If only you will be quiet.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: T'ould man's getting crazy, I'm thinking.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: And have patience — now only a little patience.

div.stage: Rural expostulating, followed by Tom , grumbling.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Decorated in Arabesque, furnished very richly in buhl and marqueterie, divans, prideux, causeuses, bergères and dormeuses, covered in chintz; tambour frame, and work tables — ornamental writing table — alabaster French clock — Indian screen, &.mp;c.
Lady Pompion discovered reclining in a bergère, with her feet shawled on an Ottoman, and a spaniel in her lap.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Really, parliament ought to do something for that dear creature, Eugene Sue. I'll speak to the Earl about it
(she strikes a gong).
Enter a richly liveried Servant .
Has Willis sent out those invitations?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I am not at home this morning to any one.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lord Charles Roebuck, my lady, is expected every moment.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Oh, true! Charles does arrive to-day from Paris, well, tell him the number of my box at the Opera, and my hour in the ring. I dare say we shall meet, my nerves are not equal to receiving him now —
(loud and peculiar knock)
Good heavens — can that be he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No! my lady — that is Lady Alice Hawthorn's tiger.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'm not at home — I could never survive that girl an hour.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Then prepare to die, my dear aunt, for here I am for the day — ha! ha!
(to the Servant )
tell my groom to bring my carriage at nine.
(to Lady Pompion )
You will excuse my leaving your table at so early an hour, but I never miss the last act of the Barbiere.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My head — my head — the salts — the restoratives.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Tom — bring the liqueur case.
[Exit Servant .
Ha! ha! well, my dear, I heard of Charley's arrival, so I have come to dine with you — tell me, what is he like? — partiality apart — is he worth making love to?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Charles has not yet arrived home.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Why, I saw, by the Post , that he arrived in town last night.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Indeed! ah! well! — he might as well have sent a card.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: A card! has he not rattled you up at four in the morning — broken in your knocker panel, and pulled up the bell by the roots? Has'nt he dislocated your wrist and kissed you into an asthma? has'nt —

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Lady Alice, my son has not the manners of Abdelkader to take my establishment by such a surprise, and I trust he always leaves bells and knockers to the servants.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Does he? then Charley's occupation's gone indeed. But, apropos , Georgy, what fun I had with your old Earl last night at Almack's, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My old Earl!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: He came in, thawed with a decent dinner; the premier's Steinberg had given the cadavre a bloom, 'pon my life he talked impudence to me.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: The Earl of Pompion!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
It would have delighted you to watch such signs of restored animation. A knot of politicians had nearly secured him — politics at Almack's — I darted in amongst them crying "treason," seized Pompey himself and whirled him into the most delirious polka
(hums a polka).

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: A polka!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Toe and heel, as I'm a widow and a sinner; we threw Jullien into extacies, till I restored the Home Secretary to his party — a wiser and a better man.
Enter Lord Pompion .
Didn't I, Pompey?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Lady Alice, et tou jours gaie , where's my countess?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Not up yet, look
(points to Lady Pompion who is pulling her spaniel's ears)
or stay, she is making Bichon's toilette.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I forgot to mention that I expect Mr. Coke, of Yorkshire, on a visit, he has lately been returned for Ashby, and I want his interest and a loan to secure Charles for Closeborough — we must shew him attention.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Very well, write down his name and I'll send it to the housekeeper.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Long live old English hospitality.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: He has some of his family with him.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: They can have the britzska, and you must manage something for their Opera — leave it to the housekeeper.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Talking of visitors, I have invited acouple to you.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To us!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes — Colonel Rocket and his daughter, old friends of mine — my bonbonniere in Brook Street only holds me and my plagues, but, fortunately, having a card of yours in my case, I thought how glad you'd be. I mentioned six as your dinner hour. Don't be anxious — they'll be here in a minute.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: How rash — he may be of the opposition.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
An East India director, with two boroughs,
(aside)
rabbit ones.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Is the girl presentable?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Met them at Devonshire House —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Two boroughs! my dear Alice, you are rash, but you mean well.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Of course I do — only think of two boroughs, Pompey.
(aside)
A half-pay colonel, with less interest than a treasury clerk, but a glorious old fellow. I'll bet he'll kiss the Countess in a week — what fun!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lord Charles Roebuck.

div.stage: Enter Roebuck , followed by Littleton Coke .

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: My dearest mother!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Ah! Charles, how d'ye do, dear?
(lifts her eye-glass)
Bless me, how brown you're grown — for heaven's sake take care of Bichon, there,
(shakes his hand over the dog)
have you brought me the Eau de Cologne?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Yes, everything — but, my dear mother —

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Dear — how old he looks for a son of mine.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: But undoubtedly improved —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: My dear father, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: A Pompion, decidedly.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Tell me, Charles, your Italian is Roman — and — ah! I see you wear Bouquet du Roi . I understood that esprit d'Isabella was the court scent at the Tuilleries, just now.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Of course your present appearance is the remains of a diplomatic compliment to the Court of Versailles — very judicious —

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I trust, Charles, you have picked up no foreign immoralities — I mean, you go to church, sometimes, we have a pew at St. George's, and, apropos, have glacé silks gone out yet, in Paris?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Really, dearest mother, I didn't notice.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ah! boys are so thoughtless.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: You don't make yourself remarkable in dress or equipage, Charles.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I hope you have no penchant for liaisons with public people or unmarried women, dear.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Every notoriety, which is not political, is hurtful.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
Lord P.
sp.p: Apropos — you'll find in my room a list of the doubtful ones of our party, so that you may know where to lose your money, at Crockford's — of course, you will not enter any of the lower gaming clubs — and, bye the bye — be cool to Vernon.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: My dear father — my schoolfellow, Dick Vernon, once saved my life.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Possibly — but he voted against us on the Barbadoes Bill, and he has talked of conscientious principles, and in presence of the Premier — in short, he was omitted in the Premier's dinner yesterday — of course, you speak German?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Do you bet?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Do you Polk.?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Blest voice! — surely — it is —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Your cousin Alice — how are you Charley?
(he hesitates)
all right — go on, I'm human nature —
(he kisses her)
what's your friend's name? we are acquainted I know, — but I can't recollect who he is!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
Coke — I had almost forgotten him — what can he think of my cold reception; how frigidly they will receive him — I am fairly ashamed to —
(aloud)
my lord and lady, mother, allow me, Mr. Coke.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Coke! of Yorkshire?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Ashby?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
My dear, sir, I'm delighted to see you,
(shaking him by both hands)
delighted, this is an unexpected pleasure, to find in you a friend of my son's, allow me — the Countess — Mr. Coke, of Ashby.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Coke, of Ashby! Take care of Bichon, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Mr. Coke — Lady Alice Hawthorn with whom the whole world is in love.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Speak for yourself, sir
(she speaks aside with Coke .)

div.stage: Lady Pompion sounds a gong, enter Servant who unwraps her feet, and wraps the dog in the shawl.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
You will excuse me, Mr. Coke — the business of the nation — till dinner, eh? sans adieu .
(shakes his hand)
Charles, I can spare you a moment, follow me to my study.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Adieu, Charles! au plaisir , Mr. Poke, by — by Alice.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Adieu, Bichon.

div.stage: [Exeunt Lady Pompion , R. followed by the Servant , carrying the dog. Lord Pompion , L.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
What can this mean, Coke received with such fervour — and this — this is my return after three years' absence, well!
(going)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I say, Charley, are glacé silks out in Paris?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: By heaven!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Ah! ah! I hope you don't swear, I mean in English ah! ah! ah!
[Exit Roebuck , L.
(aside)
So! a pair of recruits to my staff.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
And this glorious creature is the deadly widow whom Roebuck gives up without a sigh.
(a pause)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Coke, if you have nothing droll to say give us your maiden speech; on what question do you come out?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: To love, or not to love?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I'll settle that — to love — carried, eh?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Without a division
(kisses her hand)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Hang the fellow's impudence. Well, if you can't say something funny, make me cry; I haven't cried since my marriage except with laughing. You are on a visit here, ah! you will find it a horrid bore.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I can view it only as a paradise at present; when your ladyship leaves it I may see in it a desert.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Are you an old friend of my cousin's?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lord Charles and I entered Eton on the same day, and never parted for nine years — I may say we are brothers.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I have a secret with which I mean to electrify the old folks here — I want a partner in the scheme — can I trust you?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: With your whole heart.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Miss Rocket, a friend of mine is in love with my cousin Charles here, don't stare! — I found it out, and have asked her on a visit.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: To supplant yourself — why the earl sent for Roebuck home, to — expressly — to — marry you.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Me! oh, the old fox. Ha! ha! so — so! — so much the better; I'll teach him to keep his intrigues within Whitehall — to begin then, let's be friends.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ah! beware, Lady Alice, the friend of a young and lovely woman, should have sixty years, at least, and holy orders for his qualification.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Young man, take my advice; a woman never likes her lover to be more careful of her character than she is herself,
or too provident in his heart's economy; your sex arrogates too much on the solitary advantage, which nature has given it over ours.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You are born without reputations: — what club owns you?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: None!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Right — allow neither your opinions nor your society to be dictated to you; what clique claims you?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Only one
(aside)
the Queen's Bench,
(aloud)
but they are too exclusive and confined for me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You love liberty.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: As a mistress likely to be lost.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You are a man after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I am, and I trust soon to come up with it.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What is the world?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: A gentler synonyme for vice in town.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: It seems to me that your sex is capable of but two characters — selfish politicians or reckless gamesters. Did modern chivalry erect new orders, one half nobility would range under the folds of a minister's table cloth, while the other would canonize Crockford.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Fair play, Lady Alice, or I must assert my sex.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: A challenge! tell me, as this sex of yours has adopted every effeminacy of soul in its desire to change genders with ours, when will you assume the fan and flacon?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: When ladies who have already engrafted the whip on the parasol, reveal in tops and inconceivables.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Women must adopt your habits, if left at home to exercise those duties of husbands which you are performing in every house but your own.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: At home! are ladies ever "at home," except, indeed, when under that pretext they invite the world to see their houses turned out of doors.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: To exhibit a satire upon men who regard matrimony as a ministerial sinecure.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The duties of which are only known to the deputy.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: True; men, whose friendship means a design against a wife's heart, and whose honor only retains its existence for the convenience of swearing by: — spirit, represents to them but a contempt of morality, while to pay, has reference to nothing but visits.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Ahem!
(aside)
she's becoming personal.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Aha!
(aside)
that hit him in the conscience.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Were I a woman, such a contemplation of society would almost drive me to suicide.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: A fashionable alternative and genuine French. I've thought of it — but decided on not doing the world the honour of cutting it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What a gorgeous creature. Can I believe that such an angel could ever be my property?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Now you are puzzling whether to propose to me next week or the one after — delay it. Meanwhile make most of your time. I'll send you a voucher for Almack's — I'm a patroness, you know — here's my polka card — let's see, I'm engaged for the 1st, 5th, 9th, and 17th.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Put me down for all the rest. Enchantress, you divine my very heart.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What wonder, when you are going to swear that I possess it?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ridicule me, if you will. Yes, I confess it. I came here to see — to woo you —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.stage: (opening his hand, and applauding on it with her own, as she eyes him through her glass)
sp.p: Bravo — not bad — get up now, there's a dear man. I promise not to flirt with any one else for one calendar week — there, don't be vain; I once patronized a boy in the guards for two days, and now he won't enter the pit of the opera, during an aria, for fear of engaging the atention of the house.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Torturess —
(pauses).

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You leave it in mine?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Certainly, till you have kissed it — hang the fellow he does not think I'm gone so far in love with him as to snatch it away.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I know not what to think, but this I know, that I'm the happiest wretch you ever doomed to misery.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Aha, my little congreve — I've been looking for you everywhere.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: So, colonel, I proved a sort of invisible shell, eh?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Only twice as mischievous, I do believe one like you would unman a whole fleet. Ah I your friend in the army?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: On my own staff! Colonel Rocket — Mr. Coke.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Coke! any relation to Cook, of the 23rd? no! ah! sorry for it! brave fellow — cut in two by a chain shot at Pullinabad, was knocked down by his top half myself — gallant fellow — bought his kit for 100 rupees.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Where's Kate?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
I picqueted her in the hall with the baggage — happy to make you acquainted sir, — brought her up for a soldier's wife — perfect in her facings as a light company, and can
manoeuvre a battalion with any adjutant in the service; look at her walk, thirty inches regulation pace — head up — left leg forward — perfection! that's the way to put a girl into the hands of a husband, sir.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: She twists the old fellow round her finger like a purse.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Hollo! that's her discharge — she is retiring upon her supports.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Here she comes, as wild as game in July.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Observe, how steady she will file in — right wheel.

div.stage: Miss Rocket runs in, her bonnet hanging on her neck.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: He's here — I saw him — I —

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Hollo! fall in — halt, the devil — discipline.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Yes, my dear father, presently — but, I believe he lives in this very house.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Report yourself, who?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: The gentleman who kissed — I mean, who assisted me when we were upset — he rushed up to me in the hall here — and I was so — I screamed — I — here he is.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
Can I believe my eyes,
(aside, seeing Rocket )
old Chili vinegar, by Jove.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Steady, Kate — stand at ease — now, sir, might I ask why, sir, — you — you — damme, sir, — why you drive in my piquet in this way.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Really — sir — I — I —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Permit me, colonel, to introduce to you Lord Charles Roebuck, son of the Earl of Pompion, who is too happy in being your host.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Sir — your hand. No apology, enough, I accept the quarters. Roebuck, in the army — no! — any relation to Rover of the 81st, retired on full pay and two wooden legs, after Nepaul? No! no matter — my daughter, Kate Rocket — Bombay Cavalry.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
Allow me to apologise.
(aside)
Whom have I to thank for this?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Me! I'm in the secret — she has confessed all to me — I invited them here — am I not an angel?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: A divinity! How do you find Coke?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: As impudent as an heiress!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: My father mistook him for his brother, whose arrival has rectified the error — I have left him closeted with the Earl.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Now, colonel, to introduce you to Lady Pompion, your arm?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Kate, present arms to our host, and follow.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Executed with wonderful dispatch.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Discipline.

div.stage: Roebuck and Miss Rocket in earnest tête-a-tête go up.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Only they are marching without orders.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
Hollo! halt — attention.
[they go out, still conversing, without apparently hearing him.
It's nothing — a mere manoeuvre — but we mustn't club the battalion. We only constitute the reserve instead of the advance — a clever movement of Kate's?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Very —

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: What we call a diversion.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes, very diverting indeed — ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
So, now fate, I'm thy worshipper for ever — do with me what you will: — this morning I arose with fewer hopes than a Pennsylvanian bondholder; my belief in hearts was restricted to the thirteen in a pack of cards — and here I am, in a few hours, domiciled in Grosvenor Square, with expectations beyond a new railway company.
Enter Jesse Rural .
Strange — too — hum!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: They tell me Littleton is here — in this house — if I could only — this gentleman, perhaps, might — pray, sir?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Come what may to Thomas Coke, I'll never sign myself a brother.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Thomas Coke! let me look,
(takes out his spectacles tremblingly)
yes, yes, it is he — it is — he stares at me — he won't know me now.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What a strange old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I tremble to — to — ask him; if he should meet me as a stranger — or — how altered he is — in form: — perhaps he's changed in —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: By heaven! I know that face.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Mr. Coke — I — ventured — I — you don't forget your tutor — friend — Jesse Rural.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Forget you! may heaven forget me when I do.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha!
(embracing him)
bless you my child — God bless you! I knew it — I knew you wouldn't — no — let me look at you — yes — it is you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Tell me, how came you here, in town, and in this house?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Tom came up to parliament — you know he is member now for Ashby.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ha! that accounts then for the Earl's warm welcome — mistook me for him.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: So I accompanied him to town.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And he is in this house!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Yes, he is dressing for dinner. I heard that you were here, and could not contain myself — came to bring you to him; he is unaware of your presence.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What, creep on my knees to his purse like a prodigal son! In what have I injured him? He has my land, I wrote to offer to sell him the mortgages he held — he refused me.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: The same wild violent spirit he always had — just the same, ha! ha! Littleton, listen to me, my dear boy; Tom loves you, you don't know him. When we went to your chambers this morning; —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
You, you,
(aside)
it must have been them whom Bob announced, and I mistook — for Scriven and Craft.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Tom was prepared to forgive you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Forgive — 'tis I who claim that office.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ha! he! there he flies out again — the dear boy.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Let him ask my pardon — I entreat you will not attempt a reconciliation; it would only sever us more certainly.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
But, listen — my darling child, listen — Tom always meant to give you the money you asked for —
(aside)
God forgive me
(aloud)
see, here is the very, very sum — look — bless you, take it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
How — and —
(aside)
this is impossible — ha! I see — 'tis the old man's own savings with which he would conceal Tom's parsimony.
(aloud)
No, no — not a farthing —
(aside)
how can I refuse it?
(aloud)
it comes too late.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Too late, why,
(aside)
I was so delighted to find at last some use for these things — what shall I do with you? you come too late —
(aloud)
Here comes Tom.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Do not attract his notice to me; let me manage this meeting — the earl supposes we arrived together — hush.
(sits with Rural , R. )

div.stage: Enter Lord Pompion , and Tom Coke , L. , Lady Pompion, Rocket, Lady Alice Hawthorn , R. , dressed for dinner, followed at a distance by Roebuck and Miss Rocket .

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Your observations, Mr. Coke, are full of justice and originality.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Hardly adapted for the house then, my lord.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: In the army, Mr. Coke?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, sir, I'm it yeomanry, if that'll do, though a trust I shall never require ta know ma duty.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: How, sir, you are nervous.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, not so, it requires courage to tak the life o' an enemy, but it wants more than that to be called on to strike at the heart of a neighbour — I confess, I look with more pity than pride on the ranks of brave fellows, marked out for slaughter with red on their backs like my sheep.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Necessity, Mr. Coke.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Not the less sad for that, my lord.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Who would not die in defence of such a city as London? How did it strike you?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: As big — but not enough to hold the evil done in't.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Surely, sir, you consider our streets are splendid.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, but not as glorious as the Heaven they shut out. Since I came into this city I haven't seen a fair inch of blue sky, or a blade of green grass. Stop — I did though — yes, I did see a puir sickly plot penned up in a place they called a square, looking, for all the world, as if they'd put nature in a pound for straying into town.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ha! ha! sir, yours will be a distinguished voice in the house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And yours is the most musical and honest one I've heard since I left Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Here's a hand belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: By Heaven, can she be smitten with him already?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Dinner, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Colonel Rocket, her ladyship — permit me.

div.stage: [Leads the way, followed by Rocket and Lady Pompion .

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: You'll favour me.

div.stage: [Offers his arm to her, on her L.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lady Alice, my arm is at your service.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ha! — it — it — must be.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Your — brother, I believe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Here — and I — dom it — I canna help it
(affectionately
Yes, it — is my brother.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I fear, your ladyship, they wait for us —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: True — they do

div.stage: [Takes Tom's arm and goes up. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: My brother, and my rival, be it so.

div.stage: [walks violently up and down, followed by Rural .

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Don't be violent my dear, boy —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Yes — I will not let her see how she can wound me, and him — 'twould be too deeply gratifying.
( Rural takes his arm.)
I will go — yes.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: That's right.

div.stage: Littleton takes fierce strides, Rural running to keep up with him, suddenly Coke stops.

sp.speaker: Coke.
sp.p: Yet can I endure, without betrayal — I must.

div.stage: Roebuck and Miss Rocket have entered during the dialogue, and seating themselves at the back, remained in close tête-à-tête.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Ahem! dinner, my lord,
(a pause; he goes behind their causeuse)
dinner, my —

div.stage: [They start up confused, Roebuck looks sternly at the Butler , and they exeunt followed by Butler , bowing.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: SCENE. — THE DRAWING-ROOM IN LADY POMPION'S HOUSE.

Arch C. draperied and surmounted with a rich cornice, discovering an inner drawing-room with a fireplace in C. F. Fireplace and fire, T. E. R. Windows S. E. R. and L. , draperied in rich crimson damask and gilded valences. The room is decorated in white and gold, with a bouquet pattern, a brilliant chandelier branches between the windows, and divans and consols, R. and L. , mirrors and chandelier in the inner room.

Lady Alice is discovered playing at a piano, U. E. L. , Tom Coke leaning over it, Rural is seated L. on a prideux, reading a pamphlet. Lord Pompion and Colonel Rocket are walking up and down, from L. to R. corner of the inner room, while Lady Pompion is lying on a sofa opposite the fire, a Servant is offering her coffee on a salver, while another Servant waits with liqueurs. Littleton Coke is playing with her spaniel, but watching Lady Alice and Tom. Roebuck and Miss Rocket are seated on a flirting vis-a vis, pretending to play ecarte on a small ornamental table.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: My opinion is, that a submarine battery is attracted to the keel of the vessel, and exploded by concussion.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Bless me! had Guy Faux lived in these times, what would become of the House of Peers?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Pooh! vote me a hundred thousand pounds, and I'll undertake to blow up both houses.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I propose.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I won't let you, I've a beautiful hand.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
I've been admiring it.
(plays.)

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p:
I take your heart.
(takes a trick.)

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
I wish you would take my hand with it
(plays his last card.)

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I do, the game's mine; what were we playing for?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: For love —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p:
Exactly, that means for nothing.
(they flirt, aside.)

div.stage: Lord Pompion watches them, while Colonel Rocket joins Lady Alice Hawthorn .

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Your ladyship, may I entreat your
sympathy and beneficence in favour of a subscription I am raising for a poor creature, a widow with eight children?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Widows never appear to have less — have I seen the case in the Morning Post ?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Not that I am aware of.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Pray, sir, let me see your list — what people of importance have subscribed?
(to Coke )
one gets one's name mixed up with such canaille in these charities.
(to Rural )
In whose name, sir, is it raised, pray?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: In that of the most bountiful Dispenser of All Good.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ah! sorry — we are not acquainted.

div.stage: [she turns away, and takes coffee from the Servant .

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Colonel Rocket, a word.
(they advanec)

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! you strange creature — I declare I will storm Sykes Hall, next September.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: This is done to torture me — and succeeds.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We will shew you old English sports.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Suppose, after my invasion, I should determine to occupy.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'd ask no better.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The devil!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Mr. Coke, my poor Bichon!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Really, I —
(aside)
damn the dog.
(coming down)
I can uffer this agony no longer — although she may despise my want of pride in suing her after my exhibition of ill-temper — what would I give to be able to affect her indifference? No! after all my oaths to bring her to submission first — Here I go.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: In a word, Colonel Rocket, your attentions are thrown away — My dear sir, recollect — the son of a peer!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: My — daughter.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: With all respect — I have other views for him, and excuse my candour — but the Pompions came over after the Battle of Hastings, and have never yet mingled with anything but Norman blood.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Damn it, my lord, Kate Rocket need not look up to blood royal — her mother was the Begum of Currypore, princess of the first caste; she was the only one of her family my guns had left alive — I took her in a brisk charge after she had shot two horses under me, no offence, my lord — but her ladyship don't shew such blood as that.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
No! My countess is not of a fusileer family — pardon me, I feel my honesty is almost plebean, but should your daughter's name suffer by contact with my son's, don't blame him.
(goes up)

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
Blame! certainly not, I'll blow his brains out,
(calls)
Kate!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p:
Colonel.
(joins him)

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: We leave this house to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p:
To-morrow!
(looks at Roebuck )

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Orders given, no appeal — duty — damme — ha! ha! that peer is as proud of — of the Norman puddle that stagnates in his heart, as if his country had ever seen any of it — ha! Battle of Hastings! ha !a pretty affair that must have been — when there's no mention of it in the Army List! ha — damme if I think there ever was such a battle.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.stage: (to Lord P. , who has been speaking aside to him)
sp.p: Be careful! wherefore, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I have discovered that all the Government interest he possesses is confined to 3 per cent. on 5000 l. , and he is no more an East India Director than my valet. Need I say more?

div.stage: Littleton leaves Lady Alice Hawthorn , who has been devoting herself to Tom , and advances.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: 'Tis useless. I have yielded up my will, soul, and all to her — I cannot escape her torture — struggling wounds me more than patient suffering. Heaven — to what despicable slavery can manhood be reduced!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My dear boy, what's the matter? why do you look so darkly at Tom? is he not your brother?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is he so — why then has he crossed me through life — has he not devoured my inheritance — am I not a beggar?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: No — not while a roof and crust are mine. Littleton — listen to me — I left my cure, my people in the country, for the holy purpose of uniting you again: I entered this wilderness to bring back a lost sheep.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Then you should have come unaccompanied by the wolf — I care not to avow it — I am madly in love.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My goodness!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Servilely — despicably — meanly — infatuated — willing — anxious to exchange degrading worship for contempt — to return blind grovelling adoration for indifference!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: The dear impetuous boy.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Look around you, and judge if I have cause for misery.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Misery — cause — let me see,
(puts on his spectacles, looks round, sees Roebuck and Miss Rocket .)
Oh! oh! oh! there it is — well — poor Littleton! perhaps I can do something here! it may not be hopeless.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: 'Tis my opinion there's honest nature in that girl, and wholesome feeling too — I'll wait and see if it be his lordship's Burgundy, or my reason, that's at work upon my heart — Minister.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Well, Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: You noticed yon blithe lass, I'm thinking.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I did, Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Do't again — I'm not clear about it; but its more than likely I'm in love.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Bless me, how very remarkable.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I have hesitated, minister, because I thought Littleton did seem that way inclined.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Thank heaven, I can answer no, to that — no, Tom, he is in love, but 'tis there.
(points to Miss Rocket )

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ar't sure?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: He owned it to me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
'Tis loike him — to drag a poor trusting, loving girl from comfort here — to share his discontent.
(goes up.)

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
I'm determined — yes, that will do — the bequest, left me by the father of these boys, I have never thought of till this moment — 'tis not a fortune, but with my vicarage — enough — enough, Littleton shall have her — I — I will provide for all — they shall come to me, and my happiness will be too much — more than I deserve; then Tom will relent, I know his good heart, and I shall be blessed in their union once again — how shall I begin?
(thinks apart)

div.stage: Enter the Groom of the Chambers , with shawls.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The carriage waits, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I had almost forgotten the opera.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Mr. Coke, a seat in our box is at your service.
( Tom shawls the Countess .)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
O, too happy,
(to Lady Alice )
does your ladyship accompany us?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I don't mind, though I have a box of my own on the pit tier — Russell, have they sent my Brougham?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Not yet, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Then I'll follow you, for I hate three in a chariot.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Charles dear, do take Bichon to his valet. I think he's sleepy.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Colonel, shall we stroll down to the house?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Your lordship's pardon — I've an appointment at my club — the Oriental.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Here, one of you men, run and see if my carriage is come.
(to Littleton )
You'll do, and ask my footman if the lorgnette is in the pocket. There, do go, run.
[Exit Littleton Coke .
Colonel,
(taking Rocket's arm)
suppose you propose me at the Oriental?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Would you not prefer being a member of the Jockey Club?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
No! I could amuse myself with your old drolls, but
nothing appears to me so slow as your soi-disant fast man. Come, do propose me.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: You would kill us all off with laughing in a week.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Do, now!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: No, no.

div.stage: Lady Pompion and Tom go out, L. , Kate , following Roebuck , with dog shawled up, is going, R.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I'll remain here and consider how my hopes are to be realised. At last I have a moment's leisure.

div.stage: [Sits at the back. Kate returns for her handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Miss Rocket — one word.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p:
Don't detain me!
(aside)
I must let him know how valuable his time is, or he will let me go.
(aloud)
Let me say farewell, my father leaves town to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: To-morrow! — then there is no time for delicacy.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Not a mom — that is, I mean, let me go — how I tremble —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Lean on me!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Thank you. I am so faint —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Do, if we are discovered?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I will? What am I saying?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: How very extraordinary — here's more love. It appears to me that the young people in this house don't do anything else.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.stage: (to Miss Rocket hides her face in her hands)
sp.p: Kate — dear Kate — need words pass between us, doesn't this speak for itself. Your father's tyranny will defeat itself, and excuse this precipitation of an avowal.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: My father's tyranny! — you mean that of the severe and haughty earl.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: No, dearest, fear nothing from him — I am his son, 'tis true, and, as such, will yield him the obedience I ought. But 'tis to my children, not to my father that I am answerable for the choice of my heart — I claim, therefore, my freedom and your hand — assure me that I have won it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Spare me a reply — but, my father —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: On what pretext can he withhold his consent?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: On the earl's dislike to our union.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Ha! I see — my father has already spoken to the colonel — that accounts for his sudden departure.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I fear so — but don't mind papa, he's nobody —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: How — are not his orders peremptory?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Yes — so is his obedience — he's a dear noisy old man — the worst-tempered, best-hearted creature in the world; he's fond of reviewing, so I let him burn his powder, and then I march him home again — ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I took him for a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: He? why he has the heart of a woman — when my mother died, before I was two years old, I've heard that he would watch me like a nurse — fearing to touch me, but envying the Ayeh to whom I was confided.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: But you had some female relatives?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Not one — nor did I feel their absence. I felt myself as our mess-room used to toast me, "the fair colonel." Oh, Charles, you will love him so — could you have seen him as I have, under the scorching sun of India, pacing along the ranks, trying to inspect the men with a regulation frown, and swearing down their honest murmurs of "bless his old wig and spurs," 'till suffocated with their benedictions, with tears in his eyes, he'd cry — "Get out of the sun, you mutinous rascals! Dismiss! I'll flog every man of you — march — God bless you, boys." Oh, I could have cried with pride.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: And when you leave this, where do you go?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: To our villa at Closeborough.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The very seat which I was to represent; the election, or rather the nomination, occurs to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Another obstacle — my father's politics.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I am a martyr to them — I abdicate the honor in favor of Littleton Coke — but have you no excuse by which your departure might be retarded?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I — yes — my father's gout has prevented him lately from accompanying me in my daily ride; he has consented to allow me a groom of my own, I have not yet selected a —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: A groom! a moment — ha! will you take one of my recommendation; one in whose confidence you may rely as in my own.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What do yon mean?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Rely on me — I mean all for the best.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I have no will but yours.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
My angel!
(kisses her)

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Hollo there — Kate — recover arms — the devil.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: My father.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: You — you — you — here's mutiny, and you, sir, how dare you, against general orders?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Hush! my father, should he overhear.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Dont think your Norman blood will —

sp.speaker: Kate, Roe.
sp.p: Hush I entreat — the Earl We shall be ruined.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
What do I care whether he hears or not — I hope he will — you pair of disaffected mutineers.
(gradually breaking out)
Don't imagine I want to steal a recruit from your family into mine — because I'd see it —

sp.speaker: Kate, Roe.
sp.p: My dear father! he's only in the next room. The Earl — for heaven's sake —

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
Very well then — don't Earl me — who's the Earl? — you — hark ye, sir,
( Kate throws her arms round his neck)
you may have come over after the battle of Hastings — though I can't say I see much glory in arriving when the fight's done — but I can count scars for every branch in your geological tree — so look ye, if you think there's any ambuscade here to catch your lordship, fall back — your retreat is still open — but if you try a surprise on my baggage here, damme look out for a warm reception.

div.stage: Kate stops his mouth with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, Colonel, I heard it all.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Ruin — ruin — nothing can prevent this simple old fellow from committing our secret with my father.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: You have brought on a twinge of the gout, you have, you graceless baggage — then what do you care — you'd run off with the first fellow whose grandfather came over after the battle of Hastings, and leave your infirm old father with nothing to swear at but his crutch. If I had a family poodle to leave my money to, damme I'd cut you off with a rupee — give me a kiss — I would, you — oh! — don't laugh at my sufferings — oh!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
My dear old friend, one word,
(aside)
what shall I say?
(aloud,)
you never thought I was making love to that lady.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: It did strike me — but if not, what were you making?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Why, can't you guess?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: No! making love is very unlike anything else I know of.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: You are right — I was — but — but — not on my own account.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I pressed the suit for — for a friend — in fact, for Coke

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: For Littleton?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Don't tell me —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p:
No — but —
(speaks aside)

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: You must be aware that I am destined by my father for Lady Alice — and — of course — I — I am devoted to her.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: And Littleton was jealous of you! generous young man! how he will repent when he is aware of his unjust suspicion; I know my dear boy is in love with the lady, he has confessed it to me.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The devil he has!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Now leave the rest to me —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Oh! there's some mistake here.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
I will get the Colonel's consent — I'll do it at once before
I see Littleton — not a word to him. Let me surprise him with it.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: My dear fellow, you must aid me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Old Rocket leaves this to-morrow, taking Kate with him. I have determined to accompany them.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The lady wants a groom.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You never mean to undertake the place.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: When I have removed these foreign decorations from my chin and lips, I'd defy the eyes of Argus to know me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: But the election to-morrow!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Egad! that's true — and my father expects Mr. Bribe, his solicitor and parliamentary agent, every moment to arrange accounts for my nomination. What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: We must prevent the interview.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: How.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I'll engage him at a larger fee. We must find some one to represent a partner in his firm, who is unknown by sight to your father.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Crawl's the man.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Then Crawl shall enjoy an honest reputation for a day, in the person of Bob.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Is he equal to it?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I'll back him with odds at anything, from winning a kitchen wench, to a speech from the woolsack.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: He is here — where shall I find him?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Have you any spot in the house dedicated especially to the maids and mischief, if so, elevate your voice in that quarter.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p:
Sir! sir!
(looks about.)

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Here he is.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I've sent your address to the Closeborough Independent , sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: My address!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p:
To the free and enlightened electors — you'll find it sharp and undecided, sir — I've been rather abusive in my allusions to your lordship, but one cannot be political without being personal, therefore, when I refer to your lordship, from the hustings to-morrow as only falling short of a fool by being born a knave, and the disgrace you are to the aristocracy.
(to Littleton .)
Oh! sir, I've not read the debates for nothing.
(to Roebuck .)
Your lordship will understand me to speak professionally.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Why — you — you —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Never mind, wait till I can afford to pay him his wages, I'll not forget you.
(to Bob )
We require you to adopt the name and character of a gentleman who is expected here, and to personate him before Lord Pompion: can you do it?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: That depends upon whom he is

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Crawl, the attorny and agent.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I thought you spoke of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Nonsense sir, can you play the attorney?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Facilis descensus averni, as Virgil said when you were at college, sir. I'll adopt the character, but I'm afraid my honesty will show through and spoil the assumption.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: No fear of that. Accompany Lord Charles, he will give you instructions.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
'Tis a fearful alternative, but there is no time to invent!
(to Bob )
this way. Gare! here comes the widow!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
The widow, and once more alone, ha! I feel that if I could mask my impetuosity for a moment, I might at least discover my position, but my love is in its own way, and —
Enter Lady Alice Hawthorn .
(aside)
Here she is.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
I thought he had gone without me — ha! I almost believe I like the fool.
( Littleton sits and writes)
I must discover why these brothers do not speak.
(aloud)
I was thinking of trying the opera for an hour, Mr. Coke.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Not a bad idea
(writing)
my distracted love is too perceptible
(aloud)
the opera, ay!
(aside)
could she have reused to accompany Tom and the Countess, to secure a tête a tête with me, I dare not hope it:
(writing)
in the fond hope.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Why I do believe the fellow is writing a love etter.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Grisi — yes — ah — eh — I beg your pardon — you'll allow me to ring for your carriage.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: So he thinks he is sure of me — oh! yes — hang his smirking self-sufficient grin — that letter is to me — now if I liked him less, I would torture him till — why — he is not going to seal it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lady Alice, I remarked a minute signet ring on your lovely hand, will you favour me with it for an instant?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Nonsense; it bears the motto "L'amour est."

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Love defunct, excellent. You keep it to seal your death warrant, to the heart of a discarded lover
(seals the letter)
Spirituelle — ha!
(kisses the ring and returns it to her finger kissing her hand).

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Well — ahem —
(aside)
he does not give it me,
( Littleton writes)
he directs it — really, I —
( Littleton extinguishes the taper and advances)
feel very — oh, here he comes — ha! he was too nervous to speak — I —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lady Alice —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
His voice trembles — ha! —
( Littleton walks round her and takes up a shawl)
he's swimming round the hook.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You were talking of the Opera —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: The float sinks.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Allow me, before you go —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I have him!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: To shawl you.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Sir! —
(aside)
He's off.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Happy shawl! — Blest cashmere! — why was I not born amongst you to be continually hugged round such a lovely form as this.
(shawling her)
Allow me to ring for the carriage.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Hang the fellow, I'll have that letter if I die for it.
(aloud)
A warm correspondence that of your's, if I may judge by your escaped expression.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Aha! 'tis a bite, as I expected — now I'll play with her a little.
(aloud)
Warm, oh yes, and apropos, you may be of some assistance to me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Assistance!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes; you might deliver the letter. I am sure the interest you took in me this morning will excuse the confidence I ask you to give us.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Us!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Yes.
(gives the letter)
I'm an humble aspirant to —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Miss Rocket.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You seem surprised.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Surprised! — and the lady she encourages you?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Look at me, and don't wound my feelings by reiterating the question.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And your — your — ha! ha! — your protestations to me —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Egad, that's true. I forgot — oh don't mistake me — when I offer Miss Rocket my hand, allow me to express at the same time, my wild adoration of your ladyship in the abstract — it's a fearful mania of mine.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! and you thought I reciprocated your empty expression of — Oh!
(aside)
I shall choke!
(aloud)
Perhaps you even imagined I was in love with you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Disabuse your mind of it, I beg — you flatter yourself!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You are not in love with me?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ah, true — how could one expect heaven to endow you with beauty and sense at the same time.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And do you imagine, sir, that I will permit my friend to remain in ignorance of your treachery?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Quite the contrary. I feel convinced you will instantly apprise her of the fact — Oh! I don't wish to take her at any disadvantage — I wish to owe nothing but to the unaided dynamics of personal appearance.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
The egregious puppy — my heart should disinherit him — cut him off with a sigh — but that I feel it has quitted this world
(touching her heart)
without a will.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
She loves me, and now begins to feel it. As I proceed I gain more confidence.
(aloud)
You seem rather animated, sorry that I'm compelled to leave alone with your feelings, excuse the imputation.
(eyeing her)
I see you possess those inconveniences; they impart expression, and are amusing enough to observe — but must be very troublesome in their manufacture.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I would esteem this man a brute, but 'twould be a libel upon quadrupeds, for he wants their animation.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You are bored I see — regret I can't amuse — possessing only the ability to be amused. Shall I ring for your dog or my brother?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Don't trouble yourself! were I inclined to laugh at anything you would do, very well.
(aside)
I could cry, but I won't.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Farewell! I tear myself away.
(looks at his watch)
I'm agonized with the necessity, but I see the ballet has commenced, and I would not miss the Truandaise , for a thousand.

div.stage: [Lounges up and out humming an air.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Can this be real? — what need I care? — I'll go to the opera and find fifty lovers there, make each commit fifty follies, and revenge myself on the sex —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: What a fearful mistake I had nearly committed — the Earl has just been speaking of his son's projected marriage with this lady; I must find Tom, and tell him so — poor fellow! tis well, he has not known her long enough to feel her loss. But, how delighted Littleton will be to hear that his suspicions were unfounded; now, now, I can conscientiously promote their happiness.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yet, his fervour was so natural, I could not be mistaken in his honesty — he does love me — on my life he does.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
I must get some assistance in my plot, these young hearts are such strange things.
(aloud)
My dear young lady, I want your help in a little plot of mine; you understand these matters better than I do, and will assist me — Littleton has fallen in love.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Bless this dear old man, he's always in the wrong.
(aloud)
Ha! he has confessed it to you then.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: He is as open hearted as a child; but you will not mention it.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I think I was his first confidant, sir.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Then, you will join me in trying to reconcile these dear children, and recovering to my arms, my favorite — I mean, my dearest hope.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
I will,
(aside)
I thought it was affectation — but I am too happy to think of revenging it — yes, yes, yes, my dear, dear sir — I will be all you wish — all he wishes.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: What a kind warm heart it is.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I dare say, like young folks — ha! he has stolen to her!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: To her — who?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Miss Rocket — bless me, are you ill.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Miss Rocket! Has he then —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Confessed to me his love for her — yes — his grovelling adoration — servilely, meanly, despicably, infatuated — bless his impetuous heart!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And Lord Charles? —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Nobly presses his suit.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I cannot believe it.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My dear child, his lordship told me so himself.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Kate — tell me — are you deceiving me?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Coke is in love with you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: With me!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: He has been confessing it all over the house — to me — to him — to Lord Charles —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Why, it can't be — what meant his declaration to me!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My dear young lady, you mistook his intentions — he was wooing for his friend who was ridiculously jealous of him — Lord Charles told me just now that he was betrothed to her ladyship, and devoted to her — the earl has since said the same thing — therefore it must be true.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Kate!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Alice!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Stay, this note will decide it.
(drawing out the note)
No, I can't do it — I — at least not yet, when we are alone — may find courage.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your ladyship's carriage waits.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Kate — be a woman —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: She is — she is —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: These pair of wretches are doubtless in the stalls at the opera, directing a lorgnette battery against all the beauty in the house, let us go and shew them we can be as heartless as they.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Yes — exactly — what can it all mean — there is nothing so puzzling to an old head, as a young heart.
[ Lady Alice Hawthorn takes one of Rural's arms, and places her opera glass in his hand.
There! my dear child — don't weep.
(is going to apply her handkerchief to her eyes, when Miss Rocket takes the other arm and checks him).
Well! woman is a wonderful and mysterious thing!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Wretches — both.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Ah!
(they are going out dejectedly, with Rural between them.)

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Monsters!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Yes —
(aside)
I wonder where I'm going to.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: SCENE . — The same as Act III.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Had I been the first-born of Richelieu, and the favorite pupil of Machiavel, I could not have surrounded myself with more intrigues, plots and difficulties. Those two dear girls took me to the opera, they beguiled the way, by crying and endeavouring to discover which could invent the worst name for her lover. When we arrived I found myself amongst soldiers and footmen; then labrynths and lights; then in a little closet with one wall out, apparently for the admission of noise and glare. I was astonished into the place and amazed out of it, and thankful I am to get here again.

div.stage: Enter Colonel Rocket , with a newspaper.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
Here's news! A copy of this evening's Closeborough Independent , has been despatched to me.
(reads)
"We gladly ssue a second edition, to give the earliest publicity to the following address, which reached us after going to press: —
"To the Independent Electors of Closeborough.

"Gentlemen, — In reply to a requisition from a numerous and highly-respectable body of your townsmen, I, too happily accede to your wishes, and shall be proud to represent your opinions in Parliament, which I cannot but suppose are violently adverse to those of my noble friend and antagonist, Lord Roebuck, whose character, speaking publicly, I must despise, — but whose private character, generally, I know nothing about.
"I am, Gentlemen, your obedient servant,
"Littleton Coke."
