Hurran! now I can shew fight, now, I've outflanked his Norman Lordship. — Ha! ha! ha! I'll not sleep another night beneath this noble roof — I've despatched orders to Corporal Stripe to have the guard out, in their old uniforms — my travelling carriage will be here in two hours — I'll
canvass the whole town before breakfast. Ho! ho! damme I've never been so excited since Bhurtpore.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Here's the Colonel — I'll venture to — to — sound him about his consent to the marriage.
(aloud)
My military friend, will you allow me to ask — has Littleton acquainted you with — his intentions?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: No sir, — I wish he had, — however, accident has revealed them to me.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: And dare he hope that you will grant your consent.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Grant! I'll secure his success. He shall have Jack Rocket's interest, sir.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Then you approve of his offer.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: I could not have selected from all England a finer fellow — more after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: He is — he is —

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Noble soul'd.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Princely.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Honest, free. —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: God bless you.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: No stiff-backed pretension —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: What a kind soul you are.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: I'll lay a thousand, his father was at the battle of Hastings.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: But, your daughter —

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Kate! ay — she'll go with him, heart and soul.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: She will, she has said as much.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Bless her heart, it always says right.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My dear benefactor, don't, don't overcome me with gratitude, what shall I say or do — may I run and tell Littleton?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Tell the rascal, I'll never forgive him not coming to me at first.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: At first, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Tell him, my carriage is at his service — my house at his command.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I shall do something very foolish for joy when I get out.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Advise him to lose no time, he should clinch the affair before breakfast to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: To-morrow! is'nt that rather, rather early, eh!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Too late, sir — I like despatch.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: But the lady.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Kate! pooh! you don't know the girl, she'll spring up at five in such a cause.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Bless me!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: No more — I'm off. Remember my carriage will be at the door in two hours, let him use it.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Use it to —

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Not a word — orders given — ho! great guns! this it glorious.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Miraculous!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
I'm in the saddle again, huzza!
(twinges)
oh! the gout — I'm a rusty old arquebuse, only fit to hang up for a shew of old times; but no! I'll be charged and primed, and damme I'll go off once more if I'm blown to the devil for it — hurrah! eh! ha! ha! hurrah!

div.stage: Rural , very excited, joins feebly in his boisterous shouts.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Hurrah! bless me, how exciting all this is; ha! ha!
(he runs about)
I'm inclined to do something very frantic — I'll — oh! here's Lord Pompion.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
My dear sir.
(aside)
What is the old man about —
(aloud)
will you have the kindness to inform Mr. Coke —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Certainly, in two hours —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I mean the member, sir, that I would be happy to see him here —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Before breakfast —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: On parliamentary business —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Of course. Tell the rascal I'll never forgive him.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Mr. Rural — will you —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Spring up at five in such a cause.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: He is possessed —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Great guns, this is glorious.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Crawl, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Shew him in.
[Exit Servant .
Charles informs me that Bribe sends word that he is engaged against us by the opposing candidate; but he has proved himself a trustworthy fellow, for he has despatched an intelligent and junior partner in his firm, whom he feels assured will carry all before him. We must do something for Bribe — fidelity should be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Crawl.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Mr. Crawl?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Of the firm of Bribe, Crawl, and Treatem.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Fame speaks highly of you, Mr. Crawl, and parliament
has its eye on you. Fortune favoured me when, twenty years ago, I selected your firm for my solicitors.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I remember the era. Its date — I think — is on your lordship's first mortgage to us.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: A tenacious memory — be seated. How fortunate for us that Bribe is secured to our opposing candidate.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: He's a treasure —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: So are you —

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh, I'm a mint, my lord, a perfect mint — I'll coin you votes that shall pass current with any Committee of the House — I'll put you in for any borough in Great Britain, and return you with any majority you may please to pay for — I'll qualify you with three hundred a-year landed property for fifty pounds, and shew more voters in your interest unpolled, than there is population in the county.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Crawl!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh my lord — that's nothing.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I may conclude my son elected then.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Chaired — and has returned thanks in a neat speech which I have already prepared.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Then I may venture to dismiss anxiety from my mind — and enter on other topics.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Other topics — master didn't prime me for other topics.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Fifteen years ago —

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh, lord!

sp.speaker: Lord P
sp.p: It may be in your tenacious recollection that I confided to the care of Mr. Bribe, a boy.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh! perfectly — a perfect child — a — a mere — a — boy — a — oh I perfectly —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: The — the — son of an old and valued servant.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Female?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: No — my butler.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I promised to — to — protect — to educate — my — I mean his child — and confided the responsibility to Bribe's charge.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oho! — the Earl has been a gay deceiver in his youth — ahem! — not much of the Lothario left!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I — I — left England shortly after this occurrence, as ambassador to the court of Lisbon, — since my return — business — a —

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Of course. I see — Oh yes — I know the boy — a fine fellow he has grown an universal favorite.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: His name is Robert — but we call him Bob — familiary.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Yes. Yes.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I do assure you, there's no one for whom I possess a higher esteem, — whose interest I have more at heart.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: It does you honour.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I got him into the service of Mr. Littleton Coke.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Coke! what a strange coincidence.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: But, to-day he has obtained the situation of groom, to a Miss Rocket.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Miss Rocket! why that lady is now in this house

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Indeed! then so is Bob.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Could I — I — see him?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p:
Of course, permit me to ring.
(rings)
By the way, if you will excuse the idea, I can't help thinking that there is a considerable resemblance between his features and those of your son — our candidate.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
Bob.
sp.p:
Tell Miss Rocket's new groom to step up.
[Exit Servant .
(aside)
so, Lord Charles, you roasted me once, now I'll give you a turn.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: How agitated I feel.

div.stage: Enter Lord Charles dressed as a groom, with his moustaches and beard cut, and his hair cropped.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Step forward, young man — my lord, this is Bob.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
My father — the devil —
(threatens Bob)

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I dare not look at him —

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: His lordship is good enough to take an interest in you, Bob — for which you will feel duly grateful — ahem — Iv'e no doubt that he will even do something handsome for you — you see the reward of virtue: — I promised you, that by steady and persevering conduct, I should be able to give you a turn when you least expected it.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Expected it — the fellow is roasting me now with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I — I heartily thank his lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
The voice — the Pompion voice — I could swear to its haughty tones amongst a million.
(looks at him)
Mercy! he will betray me. Blindness would know him to be Charles's brother.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Bob are you ready to experience his lordship's generosity?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Young man — I — take some — little interest in your
— Robert — I
(checks himself)
Mr. Crawl, you will expend this hundred pounds for Robert's benefit.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I feel it as a gift to myself — every shilling of it shall be conscientiously spent on that individual. Bob, have you no tongue — mercy on me — no gratitude — there you stand — do you see, sir, 'tis one hundred pounds — thank his lordship.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Oh, the scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Thank him on your knees, sir.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
Oh, you — your, — lordship — I — I — scarcely know how to —
(aside)
damn that fellow's impudence.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Farewell, Mr. Crawl, you will let me hear of this young man from time to time
(takes a last look at Roebuck from the door).
Fatal image — poor boy — Sarah Jane — oh memory.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: So, sir, you have the daring impudence not only to ring me up, for your special amusement, but to rob my father before my face.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Vails, my lord, nothing more; besides, if I am to injure my character by adopting that of a lawyer for half an hour — the least I may be spared is the lawful plunder of the profession. Consider the risk.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I can't find him anywhere.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Mr. Rural.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: The old money-lender — he has dogged us — the bailiff can't be far off — I must find my master.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Why, — surely —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
He detects me — better make him a confidant, or he may betray me —
(aloud)
yes — yes — he — he — you look surprised — this dress —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
But where's all this
(touching his chin)
.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Ha sir! my judicious compliment to the Court of Versailles — hush — I'll tell you — it's a freak —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Law!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
Nothing more —
(aside to Rural )
— you see —
(aside)
aid me, Mercury, god of lies, —
(aloud)
I told you I was assisting Coke to the hand of Miss Rocket.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: You did — so am I.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: They — they are off to-night.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I know it — ha!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The deuce you do — well — I'm going to ride postillion, that's all.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Going down as his groom?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: No! as her's — but hush — I implore — not a syllable — could I but find Kate, without meeting my father — I have secured the servants.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Well — I had heard of young noblemen turning coachmen — but this is the first instance of one turning a groom! —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: They have gone! sir — the persons who were here this instant, do you know, have they left the house?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: You saw them?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Certainly!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Oh! then he is in the secret.
(aloud)
You know then — you are aware.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: That Miss Rocket has got another groom.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Y — e — s.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: A new character for your rogue of a son.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Ah! hush!
(seizes his arm and looks round.)

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Eh! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: My dear sir, you have gained, I know not by what accident, the possession of a secret of the deepest importance — Yes — I confess it — the person who is now engaged in the menial capacity you mention, is my son.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Of course, he is — he is going to ha! ha! ride postilnion, what will he do next.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: You will conceal this secret.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: If you desire it, certainly; I had suspicions that Miss Rocket was in love with him — but —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Miss Rocket! is it possible — my dear, dear sir, you transport me — could you but conclude a match between them.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Good gracious!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Young ladies have eloped with their grooms before now.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Why, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I know — you would start objections, I anticipate them — listen — should this desirable event take place, it may be politic for me to shew some temper, you understand —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: To be angry — but do not heed it — 'twill only be in compliment to the colonel, and to conceal my relationship — but remember, there's a valuable benefice in my gift, it is just vacant. All I can say is — consummate my hopes, and ask me for what you will, it shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
But, my lord — Lady Alice, what can this mean — any hour ago he told me that he designed Lord Charles for Lady
Hawthorn, now he would give anything to see him married to Miss Rocket. This is all very strange — if he agree to the match between his son and her ladyship, and the colonel consent to Littleton's proposals, and the young people love each other — why make any mystery? Ha! here is my boy — he seems annoyed — a —

div.stage: Enter Littleton Coke , (he walks up and down after a pause.)

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I don't think there was a fool in the house whom she did not flirt with through her opera glass. Every one noticed it — she swept over the stalls, smiling at every eager eye that was fixed on her — damme, she appears intimate with the whole subscription — and then the omnibus boxes — oh, that was awful — why every man in 'em went round into her box — they went by twos, relieving each other every five minutes, like sentries before Whitehall. She made herself the focus for every lorgnette in the pit — and not content with that, she goes round into Lady Pompion's box, turns her back full upon the stage and me, and flirts with Tom as if she had only six hours to live. I was obliged to groan in the middle of one of Grisi's finest arias — and nearly got turned out.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Littleton — fortune smiles on you — my dear boy, I give you joy — she is yours.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is she?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: The colonel says his carriage and house are at your service, and that the affair ought to be settled before breakfast to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: In all this excitement I had almost forgotten my election, and the colonel — of course! Roebuck told me he was violently opposed to his politics, he will aid my return — I'll accept his offer.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: His carriage will be at the door in an hour.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Then it shall bear me from this fatal scene of enchantment, and you will accompany me.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: May I — oh! what with you!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Forgive me, if in my moments of passion I have slighted your affection.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Slighted! let me hear any one say you slighted — my dear boy, you have been all love and — and — let's go.
(aside)
I'll write to Tom to follow, ha! ha!

div.stage: Etner Tom Coke with Lady Alice Hawthorn , laughing.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Ha! they follow to outrage me even here — I'll remain.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Coke, did you hear Lablache in the finale — ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She must have seen me leave the house in disgust before it, I felt every eye was upon me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ha! ha! he was too droll to bear. I would not hear or see anything after that — 'twould be a sacrilege.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She can be amused too!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
She loves me — I felt it — I am too full of happiness to remain unforgiving: — my heart has been knocking against my will all day long. I could not look at him wi'out a blush.
(aloud)
Brother Littleton, a word wi' you.

div.stage: Littleton Coke bows aside — advances a little — Tom hesitates.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Go, leave them to me.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Bless you — angel that you are — that is — that you will be — join those young hearts and gain an old man's last prayers.

div.stage: Rural and Lady Alice retire into the inner room. Exit Rural .

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Brother, a'm not goin to reproach you — but — but — no matter what you've been — forgive and forget. Littleton, we are brothers — flesh and blood do tingle against our parting this way — you are my father's son — the child of my mother — don't look from me, brother Littleton — because there are tears in ma eyes that a'm not ashamed of — you tremble — so do I — 'ave got my hand out — though you don't see it — you'll take it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: This charity seems strangely sudden — to what do I owe it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: To her.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Lady Alice!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Well!
(coming down, C. )

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She loves him.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I've taken a fancy to see you two shake hands, whoever begins shall be rewarded with my waist for the first polka, at Rochester House, to-night; do you hear, you statue? come, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: His hand will suffice your ladyship, for the present.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Aha! have I reduced you to submission? now I'll try on him if I have learned, by heart, the lesson he taught me an hour ago.
(aloud, to Tom )
Will you favour me with a moment's tête-a-tête , with this amusing creature?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: You command me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Will your ladyship excuse me?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No — I want you — don't go, I beg.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
She entreats, she repents.
[he pauses, she draws out a letter.
She takes a letter from her breast — 'tis to me.
(she opens it)
No — she opens it — she reads it
(she sighs)
she is affected — what can it mean?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Coke — I — I — hurt my hand this evening, and am unable to write — would you have the kindness to answer, for me, this letter, and write as I tell you?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Write as!
(aside)
what does she — perhaps 'tis from Tom — it is — I —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Pray be seated.
(he sits)
Now, will you promise me to write as I tell you?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
She smiles, ah!
(aloud)
I'll swear it.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: My dear — let's see, yes, dear sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Two adjectives?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Ye — s! "If
(reading letter)
fondest hopes, poor fellow, if you imagine my treatment of you to be cruel —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
Damme, if she isn't making me write a love letter to somebody; oh, that's too good
(rises and throws down pen)
.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Bad pen? don't stir, here's another.
(offers a pen, he looks at her and sneaks back)
"You will forgive me, your letter now before me, so full of deep affection —
(reads letter)
mad affection — ah! — has touched me to the heart."

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: If I write that, may I —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Your promise, sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Go on — your ladyship is very kind — proceed.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Let me confess, that I am at this moment inflicting upon you a torture, which, although you deserve, I am too feeling to continue, rather than see you suffer longer, let me own myself, for ever, your's.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is there any more?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes, the direction.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ha! who's the inf — gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: To Littleton Coke, Esq.

sp.speaker: Lit
sp.p: Myself — could you —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That letter —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Blank! — ha! — my own to Miss Rocket.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And you love me?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Let me sign that letter?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Which? a — this — oh! — yes, true.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Why it's blank too, you did not write a line, then.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Not a syllable, and for such a document I would have given my life; stop, we'll begin again.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No, no! had you kept your promise, you would now have possessed mine to be for ever yours.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I won't occupy you long, we'll come to "I'll be for ever, your's" at once; eh, sign a new lease of life to me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No, leave the document for me to look over.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: While suspense is making me feel like one great pulse.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: There is a prescribed time to wear mourning for a husband, and a certain time to wear reserve to a lover. I cannot throw it off so early, think how short is our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: But how much can be done in it, by hearts like ours; you are no slave to society, nor am I.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You impetuous wretch — release me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: One word' then.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Hush! — some one.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Bob!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir — sir — Crafts.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Craft!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: On the premises, saw him myself, and dressed like a gentleman — so he's serious, and means to have you — get out of the house.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: But how!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: By any way but the hall door, it's old Scriven's debt.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And its above £20, ruin — in twelve hours I should have been a Member of Parliament and free. Bob! go to the top of the staircase — watch — prevent him from coming up, by any means, tumble on him, pitch him over the banisters accidentally, any way.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: A — a — my agent — he tells me that I must start for Closeborough immediately, — every moment's delay is an agony to him.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Closeborough!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes — the poll takes place to-morrow — I must be there to-night.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: An election without me — that's enough to unseat the candidate — and only a few miles from town too.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: 'Tis not too late — with your voice in my favour.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh, if I could but escape, the Earl considers me bound to canvass for you, Charles — ha! ha! fancy stealing a march on Pompey, turning Closeborough into a modern pharsalia, to run away like Cleopatra, when the battle begun, and leave Pompey in the minority. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Not run away, only desert to the enemy.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: That's true — I'll do it — consider yourself M.P. for Closeborough — ha! ha! ha! I'll be off at once.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Hark! your carriage is driving round into the stables.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Let the horses be kept in it, I shall be ready before the earl can return.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Can you afford Mr. Rural a seat?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: With pleasure

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And me?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Impertinent! — certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Outside?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Don't dare to approach me by a mile.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: But you go to Ghuznee Lodge, where I am invited also.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Then you must occupy the village inn while I am there; now the fellow pouts again; listen, must I not preserve my deputation in tact, even from you, before marriage, or you may call it in question with yourself after it? — send to me you dear old friend, good bye.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: But stop one moment, this letter —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: 'Twas written and directed, but unsealed —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You want my ring again, love defunct.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
No, I'm alive, thus
(kisses her hand)
Paradise is regained.
[Exit Lady Alice , C.
She loves me, there is not the slightest doubt on the point — I am beloved by an angel and five thousand a-year — do I remember awaking this morning?
Enter Roebuck , in a postillion's jacket and cap.
Charles! — what's this?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Old Rocket's carriage has just driven up to the door — a thought struck me — I'll use it to elope with his daughter.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Where to?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: To Closeborough, I have not the courage to argue with my father, or with her's. I'll make a demonstration — I'll ask Lady Alice to accompany her, for form sake, I shall leave her at the Lodge, and to preserve the reputation I prize beyond my own. I will not compromise it by shewing myself to the servants, but, without dismounting, return to the Rocket Arms, in the village.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You're five minutes too late, she's engaged to me on the same road.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: To elope?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Very near — own brother to the fact.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! you're jealous of my speed in love — you're distanced — look, this is a suit of our family livery, I'll rattle down to Ghuznee Lodge in two hours and forty minutes.
Enter Bob .
Run down to the stables, and slip a saddle on the near-horse in the Brougham fly.
[exit Bob .
All right — Lady Alice is going down on my interest with Rural — she refused me a seat inside her carriage, damme, I'll take one outside her horse, and give Craft the slip — this is glorious — where is the livery, in the harness-room, I know, all right.
Enter Rural .
My dear old friend, give me your hand —
(shakes it violently)
— You said fortune smiled upon me — a mistake — she roars — don't ask me to explain — I couldn't. There's Roebuck — ask him — he's in his senses — shall I survive it?

div.stage: Rural approaches Roebuck , who is walking hastily up and down.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Tell me, what does it mean?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: It means rapture — success — madness.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Yes, I see that — but —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: You — you take Lady Alice down to her carriage, and mum — do you understand?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Not quite! but never mind.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: While the colonel's carriage waits below.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I know it does, for his lovely daughter — yes.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
Ha! the old gentleman is deeper than I thought — he sees through our plot.
(aloud)
Then my dear sir, two of the happiest dogs in London, will whirl down two of its loveliest denizens to Closeborough.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: What an extraordinary preface to marriage, had I not heard of its approval from the lips of the old gentleman, I should have considered it too wonderful to be correct.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: It's all ready sir, saddled complete.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: To your conduct is confided Miss Rocket.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh! I thought it was an elopement, my master was about.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Hush! she is here; run to her lady's maid and get her shawl, I'll not give hesitation a chance.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Oh, that's the lady — well — he has my consent.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
This appears very strange.
Enter Miss Rocket .
My dearest Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Charles! and in this dress.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Do not waste our precious time in wonder, I will explain it presently.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I have suspected you unworthily, wickedly, but Alice has made me ashamed of my folly; let me suffer something to gain your pardon.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I will, your carriage waits; suffer me to fly with you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Fly!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Only to your own house — 'Twill be enough to shew our tyrants that their opposition would be vain. Bob will conduct you to your carriage.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Bob.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Hah! oh! I never. Crawl, Bob Crawl — Alice is going —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: To elope —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
With Coke.
(aside)
Nothing convinces a woman or a judge like a precedent.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I dare not — how — to —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p:
I will waft you both down like a zephyr.
(to Rural , who is coming down)
My dear sir, join your prayers to mine — she refuses to go.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: But my father!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My dear young lady, if that's all, your father desires it — commands it — declares that the affair must be settled before breakfast to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: That's he — I must credit you.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: He ordered the carriage — have no scruples — he assured me that you would not.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Can I believe my ears?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: You may, its extraordinary, but you may —

div.stage: Re-enter Bob , with the shawl and bonnet.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Here they are, sir, only cost me a kiss, and a few promises.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I'm in a dream.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: The old money-lender here, and on such a job — ah! gets his bill out of her fortune. I must make something. Excellent, a paragraph in the Morning Post . Elopement in high life. — Littleton Coke, esq. with the great heiress and lovely daughter of Colonel Rocket. Bilious father, it's in time for to-morrow's impression, they'll make an express of it. Let's see, I'll ask a small per centage on the magnitude of her fortune — I'll try twenty thousand a year. I may get five pounds, besides, 'twill civilize the creditors.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Be assured, dearest; confide in my devoted love and farewell. Enough — I leave her to your care; farewell, dearest — now for the saddle, and I'm off — hurra for the road!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.stage: (to R. , in the dress of a postillion)
sp.p: Is she ready?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Very near, sir, all right.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Make haste?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: That's for you to do, sir —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: True — I'll introduce the turnpikes to fourteen miles an hour.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Now, madam, while the road's clear —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Road is clear — Kate —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I've my father's consent.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: To elope —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: To Closeboro'.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: That's my destination.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Another elopement — ten pounds.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: This way.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Extraordinary express.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Woman is a wondrous and mysterious thing.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: The house is a villa, with an Indian character apparently forced upon it — the lawn and shrubberies extend out, C. F. — shrubberies, R. and L. with a pagoda summer-house T. E. L. — a broad carriage entrance leads off, L. — extreme entrance — a sentry box is discovered C. in a bush.
Stripe is discovered standing in C. at the back, directing a field-glass down the avenue — a Veteran in Bombay cavalry uniform, walks as if keeping guard.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
No signs of the colonel, yet his orders were for us to be in readiness to receive him at two this morning, and here's half-past eleven — I've despatched Wilcox with the old howitzer to the top of the hill — to give us a signal; hollo! whom have we here, good light cavalry figure.
Enter Littleton Coke down the avenue, L.
Aid-de-camp with despatches from head quarters, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
I've left Bob addressing the free and independent electors of Closeborough from the hustings,
(very distant shouts)
there's another shout, elicited by his rhetoric. I believe the rascal has compromised me with every opinion on the political creed, 'twas useless arguing with him — he said 'twas no good in losing a vote for a mere promise — so, damn the fellow if he didn't promise everything to everybody;
(distant shouts)
whether I am whig, tory, or radical, will puzzle the Times to discover.

div.stage: Enter Rural from the house, R.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My dearboy, I don't know what's the matter inside, but something has gone wrong; Lady Hawthorn won't hear a word from me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She has discovered my disguise; no matter, she will readily forgive it.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Just now, she and Miss Rocket flew upon me, but all they could say was "explain, sir, explain."

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And you.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I, I ran way, because you see, explain, was just the thing I couldn't do.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: He is in the dark still, 'twill be safer to keep him so. My dear old friend, 'tis all a freak, a — a —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ah! ah! come now, you are at some of your old tricks — ho! ho! I know you are!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: We have planned a surprise, by which the old colonel and the earl will find that our young hearts have outmanoeuvred their old heads — but 'tis a secret.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Oh, let me into it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: When the colonel arrives, and discovers Roebuck, he may storm a little.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: What for? have I not his orders that you should use his carriage?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You will never mind his temper,

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Not a bit, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The earl may possibly be annoyed.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Annoyed — he'll be enraged! — ha! ha! — he said he would, oho! and you — now this is all your plot, you rogue you know it is, isn't it?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: It is, but hush, here they come — leave us.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Oh, you wild mischievous dog — oh, just what you were, when you played me those tricks in the poultry yard; when, ha! ha! you tied a gosling to my coat tail, and when I walked off, the gander nearly was the death of me — oh, ha! ha! ha! you villain!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: But go, I beseech.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: And, that fifth of November, too, when —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I remember, there —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: A squib in my snuff-box — oh, you little rogue, oh: bless you! oh! a squib, in my snuff-box!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And bless you, for the simplest, kindest soul alive.

div.stage: Enter, from the house, Lady Alice Hawthorn , with a newspaper, Miss Rocket followed by Roebuck .

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: But, hear me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Not a word — here's a fine catastrophe to your clever intrigues! here's an exposée — I shouldn't wonder if they put the whole affair into a novel, or on the stage. Fancy my follies published in penny numbers, with illustrations; or your blunders enjoying a run at the Haymarket. Bah! — I could laugh my life out at you both, if I wasn't mad with rage.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: But — my dearest —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No, sir, you have precluded the possibility of my ever being so —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Charles, what does this mean?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Hang me if I know. I have only been here a few minutes, but I found them both fulminating over that Post .

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Do you pretend ignorance, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Listen — you precious intriguers, listen,
(reads)
—
"Express. — Elopement in high life. — Enormous fortune won by a young barrister. — We understand, from the best authority, that an elopement took place last night from the Opera. The imprudent pair are — Mr. Littleton Coke, of qui iam celebrity, and the great heiress, Miss Rocket — whose fortune is said to exceed 20,000 l. a year."

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The idiots — what could have caused —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: "Second edition — extraordinary express — another elopement in high life. Last night, the young and eccentric Lady Alice Hawthorn, whose meteoric course through the fashionable world has been greeted with such admiration, eloped from Lord Pompion's house, with her cousin, Lord Charles Roebuck. It is stated, one of the parties rode postillion; our authority omits to mention which."

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: The dolts: by what mistake could this have happened?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: By none.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Roe., Lit.
sp.p: How!
True!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Quite.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
You thought to outwit me and the old people — and thus you set about it.
(to Coke )
The lady, before whom you spurred and thrashed, sir, was Miss Rocket,
(to Roebuck )
and the humble individual who admired your equitation for three hours, was your obliged servant.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What! and — I — Miss — and he — you — eh!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Coke!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
I did'nt — I —
(they look at each other astonished)

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Oh! but surely this mysterious blunder is not so serious — it can be mended by —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
What, sir — when all London know that my cousin ran away with — or rather, they don't know which of us ran away with the other — ah! you wretch!
(tears the paper)
and in the middle of the night too — and — no — I must marry Charley after all!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: And you — sir — you —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I suppose I must marry you then, after all.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And all your cunning to outwit the governors has just effected their purposes.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: But Kate — surely — you will not, by marrying him to save your character, condemn yourself to eternal misery?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Eternal what, sir? let me tell you my lord, that this is your fault, your blunder — had I been there, — I

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Mine, sir, mine!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes, yours.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: 'Tis false, sir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: False! very well, my lord;

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I repeat, sir, that —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Enough, the word suffices; but for this presence I feel you would have substituted a stronger term, but —

div.stage: [they speak apart as they go up.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: My dear Alice, they are quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: They are. I've seen so many men do it: — I know it — in a minute they'll fight.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
A duel, and on our account; no more is required to complete our destruction. Mr. Coke — Charles — will you listen?
( Lord Charles Roebuck goes up.)
There's nothing so like a mad bull as a man in a rage. Charles, Mr. Coke, you shall not quarrel, you have not the excuse of a long dinner; will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I repeat that it was his trusting to Mr. Rural that has caused this dreadful catastrophe — and to prove it I will find him.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Rural, could it — it is. Oh, my folly and weakness. Why did I entrust so dear a confidence to him! he must exonerate me from this fatal blunder — where shall I find him?

div.stage: [Goes up, meets Stripe , who is crossing — speaks in dumb show. Stripe points L.
[Exit Littleton Coke, L. and Stripe, R.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Alice, dear, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: They must not fight, because we can't spare either of them.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: But, do you — do you think, dear, we shall have to — to — exchange them?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
I don't know, love; but it's very likely, I never was run away with before, but I believe people in such predicaments always do marry, dear, if they can.
(a distant gun)
What's that?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Ready, guard, the Colonel comes — that's the signal.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Oh, Alice, I dare not meet him.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And I am ashamed!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Guard —

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Here, in this pagoda. Quick.

div.stage: Enter Colonel Rocket followed by Tom Coke, Lord Pompion and Lady Pompion .

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p:
So! good! guard turn in!
[Exeunt the men.
Stripe!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Colonel!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: The reports

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Nothing, sir, particular, till past two this morning.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: And then —

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Two carriages arrived half an hour apart.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Whom did they contain?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: The first, Miss Rocket, and an old gentleman, in the last, Lady Alice Hawthorn.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My niece, I knew that girl would come to some shocking end.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But she, Lady Alice, was alone.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Alone!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: There's a sovereign for you.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Stripe — dismiss.

div.stage: Stripe salutes and exit. They all look at each other.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I feel as if my heart was returned to my body.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Calm yourself, my dear colonel — observe my imperturbability. Your daughter has, unfortunately, eloped with her own groom; a buzz — three days' amusing variations of the story, and it is forgotten. Perhaps you will be kind enough to tell my niece that we await her here.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: As for the rascally footboy, I'll kick him into Chodah — Kate will keep, but let me only catch that old intriguer. Excuse me, your ladyship — till I've found him I'm not fit to play the host.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Where can Charles be?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I heard the shouts as we passed — perhaps they are chairing him.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Mr. Coke, favour me with your arm — the excitement has quite unnerved me.

div.stage: Tom and Lady Pompion go up, and into the house.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: 'Tis done — they are wedded — I'm sure of it.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Where can this old — my father!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Charles, or is it a —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: Of course, my lord, you have discovered all — if not, I am not in the vein to deceive you longer.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: That to achieve the hopes of my heart, I was induced to assume the disguise in which we met last night.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Then you were —

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: The groom to Miss Rocket.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: And you are — are married to her?

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: I — I —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Don't speak, sir — I know — I've been duped, and by my own son. Lord Charles! what excuse — what — what — Where's that meddling old fellow? This is his doing — his work — I'll find him — and let him know the consequences of thwarting a minister of state, and a peer of the realm.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: And I to shew him how his folly has severed two young hearts for ever.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Bless me, what a run I've had — joy has given me youth again, and I really did have a scamper — yes — but —
(staggers)
Ah! these old limbs — these old limbs.
(sits on a garden chair, C. )

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Oh! — at last — I have found you, sir!

div.stage: Colonel Rocket rushes down from the house, R.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Aha! Here you are, are you?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Yes, my dear friends, here I am.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: Let me contain myself, and respect his age and his profession. Harkye, sir, are you not ashamed of yourself?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Oh, here come the reproaches.
(aloud)
Yes; ha! ha! I am — I am.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: To connive at such a scheme — a fraud.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Ha! ha!
(aside)
he told me not to heed his anger — that he would assume it for policy, I won't —
(aloud, and in Lord Pompion's face)
Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: And by what authority did you marry my son, sir?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha!
(aside)
he thinks they're married.
(aloud)
Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: I respect your position, sir, but —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Mr. Rural, this is indecent.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: If I remain, I shall forget myself.

div.stage: Enter Lady Alice Hawthorn, Littleton Coke, Miss Rocket , and Roebuck, U. E. R.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Aha! at last, they are here, my blest ones, and I am free — give me your hands.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: When you have severed our hearts for ever.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Oh sir, you have destroyed the only hope of my existence.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What could have actuated you to such a deed; or did you betray us to the Earl and the Colonel, and agree to compromise us into obedience.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Bless me, — Littleton —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Do not look to me for help.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
I — ah —
(aside)
the rascal is keeping up the joke, because the old people are here.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Exonerate yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: What excuse can you —

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: You could not have mistaken.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Can you not see, sir, this is reality?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Ha! ha —
(chokes a laugh)
ha!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is my ruin a subject for your mirth?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
Ha! ha!
(in wonder, but continuing to laugh)

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: It is inhuman!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ah!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Or have you, — yes, her suspicions are true, and you have betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ah!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And over such a deed, you can laugh — farewell for ever!

div.stage: Rural , bursts into a paroxysm of hysterical and convulsive laughter, Lady Alice Hawthorn runs to Rural on one side, Miss Rocket on the other, while Roebuck and Littleton Coke , walk up and down, on opposite sides.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Don't weep, it was no fault of your's — you would aided our love if our foolish young hearts had puzzled your kind old head.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: He's gone! he's gone!

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
No, my dear friend, pardon my cruelty to you, I have slighted your affection,
(looking at Lady A. )
and for what?

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: My heart, but I have ruined you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p: I have, I know I have. — I have ruined my child — my — oh forgive me, will you Littleton?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p:
How shall I forgive myself, come we will leave this place.
( Rural gets up and clings to him.)
Lady Alice, one word, before I go.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: You shall not, till you have forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Forgiven!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Charles, I do repent my cruelty.

div.stage: Rural goes up with Littleton, Roebuck , and Miss Rocket, R. Colonel Rocket and the Earl speak, R.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: May I beg a moment of your ladyship's attention?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
Certainly.
(they advance, while the rest retire a little)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
A'm — a — a man of few words, and I don't think you loike me less for being honest. A've none of the ways
that the gay young fellows about town cultivate to win women's hearts with — because I never in my life intended to win but one, and I meant that should be my wife's.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
A — ahem
(aside)
this wants more than honesty, I find.
(pauses, at last loud and bluntly)
A've two estates in Yorkshire — a've twenty coil pits, and an iron hole — a've — a've four thousand honest pounds a year to spend, and a've a true English heart very much at your ladyship's service — and a've — a've that's all
(a pause)
coom — don't hesitate — be honest, as I am — say yes — or — or — no.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Honestly — I must say — no.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Well — a — that — is — at — least — honest. Yes — it is — it is,
(he is affected)
and
(huskily)
may I ask you a straight-forward question?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Do you love another?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: That's honest, too — oh, I loike it — and — ahem, that other —

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Is your brother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Littleton!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Thank you — I — that is — thank you —
(she retires)
— wi my brother — wi — very well — and — yes — I'll do't — I — will — I oul —
(calls)
— Brother Littleton.
( Coke advances)
Your — love — a — that lady.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Am not surprised at it — and a suppose you know that she loves you — she told me so — but would you, for her sake, quit gay London — would you live for her only? —

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I would, and will.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
She's worthy of a prince's throne. Brother, oh! give her then an honest heart, love her as I — as she — loves you, ahem!
(pauses)
I — Littleton, here is every paper you ever signed to me; 'ave never counted them, for they sickened me to look at. A brought them doon here thinking to restore them to you on my — but — no matter, turn a foolish vanity and
(becomes abstracted, after a pause passes his hand across his eyes)
'tis past — take them, Littleton, take back my father's gift — no — I'll buy no brother's birthright wi' a mess of potage; and besides, it would'nt do for you to go to your rich wife a beggar, and — and — Littleton, I
(chokedly and whispering)
God bless you!
(shakes his hand)

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Tom — brother — my friends, I —

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Hush! — h —
(points to the paper)
between ourselves, not a word, not even to minister; such things should be sacred, as our mother's grave — not a word.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Marry a pauper!
(they go up affectionately)

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Not quite pauper either — my lord, since he possesses nigh two thousand pounds a year, — and is, and ever will be, my only heir to twice as much again.
(shouts without)

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: They're waiting to chair the member.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Lord Charles — make haste!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Coke! Impossible, what's the state of the poll?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Here it is, at the close, Coke 218, Roebuck 2.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Bravo, I'll double your wages.

sp.speaker: Roe.
sp.p: And I'll forgive you.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Wages — forgive — another fraud!
(to Bob )
Then, sir, you — you are not Mr. Crawl. I appeal against the election.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: My lord, you are right, I am not.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Then sir, who are you?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I'm Bob —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: What meant those shouts?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Allow me to explain to her ladyship my very delicate position here?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Not a word — I — a — Mr. Littleton Coke, I congratulate you on your double election of a wife and a seat, my son.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p:
Charles, may you be happy.
( Roebuck and Miss Rocket bow as Lord P. extends his hands, Bob bows on them filially, Lord P. looks at Bob )
Not a trace of the Pompion in him.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: I trust your ladyship does not suspect this to be my manoeuvre?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Hush, I have reasons for not wishing this affair to be investigated.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: There, Kate — I don't forgive you for outflanking your old father, but damme girl, you're right — he's a dashing fellow.

sp.speaker: Rur.
sp.p:
May I unite 'em, may I? come here,
(calls Lady Alice, R. and Miss Rocket, I — , takes them under his arms)
bless your young faces, your smiles fall like sunshine on my old heart; this is a delicious moment.
(turns round, thereby bringing Miss Rocket to R. and Lady Alice, L. , pushes them towards their wrong lovers; then he turns to the audience)
There, bless you! may heaven shower its blessings on you, as it now does on me.
( Roebuck and Littleton Coke exchange Rocket and Miss Lady Alice behind Rural's back)
Here's a feast of joy, look at this happiness.
(turns round to Roebuck, L. sees him embracing Miss Rocket )
Hollo! bless me!
(turns round R. , and sees Littleton Coke embracing Lady Alice )
good gracious me, ha! what, have I mistaken — and — you — ah! I see — old heads and young hearts; well, no matter — bless you that way.
(to audience)
I see many young hearts before me, I hope you're all in love — I do — and that I could help you all. Well, I bequeath you to the conduct of the old heads; and to them I would say, did you ever see a little child leading an old blind man — how can age best repay such a charity? why, by guiding the blindness of youth, which is love: this is the last debt due from an old head to a young heart.
